History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This proposed law would require that police officers responding to noise complaints at private residences carry sound level meters and use them while investigating noise complaints.

Name: Motor vehicles parked on public streets without license plates or registration stickers.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to motor vehicles parked on public streets without license plates or registration stickers

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: The bill would prohibit individuals and entities from parking, or allowing to be parked, any vehicle on public street or sidewalk without a license plate or registration sticker attached.

Name: Prohibiting the issuance of multiple bus lane violation tickets for the same infraction within a one hour period.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the issuance of multiple bus lane violation tickets for the same infraction within a one hour period

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: The purpose of the proposed legislation is to ensure that drivers are not receiving multiple summonses for the same violation of driving in a designated bus lane.

Name: Notification of changes to parking and traffic restrictions.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to notification of changes to parking and traffic restrictions

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: In order to better facilitate communication between city residents and the NYC Department of Transportation, this bill would require the Department to mark new parking and traffic signs with a notification sign that says new, in capital letters, on a mounted metal sign. The notification would remain in place for at least 30 days and to create awareness, the current grace period given for parking violations issued in an area affected by the new restriction would be extended from five days to seven.

Name: Painting speed humps on city streets yellow.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to painting speed humps on city streets yellow.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: This bill would require the New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) to paint all speed humps with yellow or high intensity reflective paint. The bill would further require that NYCDOT repaint speed humps with yellow or high intensity reflective paint at least once annually.

Name: Creating an interagency task force on removing certain vehicles from public streets.
Title: A Local Law in relation to creating an interagency task force on removing certain vehicles from public streets

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
History.AgendaNote: Amended and Coupled on General Orders

History.Description: This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would create an interagency task force to study the City’s existing system of removing from public streets vehicles that have been abandoned or parked without license plates or proper registration. The task force would collect information about the effectiveness of current practices and evaluate potential solutions to this problem in a final report.

Name: City contracts with not-for-profit organizations in the amount of $250,000 or more.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to city contracts with not-for-profit organizations in the amount of $250,000 or more

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Contracts

Summary: This bill would require not-for-profit organizations that contract with the City in the amount of $250,000 or more to provide to the City the compensation of their three highest paid employees and the organization’s federal 990 form, which provides financial information about the organization.

Name: Review of patterns of contractual spending by the city agencies with not-for-profit organizations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to the review of patterns of contractual spending by the city agencies with not-for-profit organizations

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Contracts

Summary: This bill would amend the Charter to require the Council to review City procurement relating to contractual spending by City agencies with not-for-profit organizations and spending by not-for-profit organizations that receive City funding of over $100,000.

Name: Requiring the dept of education to implement a brief period of silent meditation in all schools on September 11th to commemorate those who perished as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of education to implement a brief period of silent meditation in all schools on  September 11th to commemorate those who perished as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center which occurred on September 11, 2001.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Education to implement a brief period of silent meditation in all schools on September 11th to commemorate those who perished as a result of the attack on the World Trade Center.

Name: Provision of information related to polychlorinated biphenyls (pcbs).
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of information related to polychlorinated biphenyls (pcbs).

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education

Summary: This bill would require that it be an affirmative defense that a property was unoccupied at the time of a noise complaint in manufacturing districts to ensure fairness.

Name: Operators of private pumping stations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to operators of private pumping stations

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection

Summary: This bill would mandate certain disclosure requirements on the owners and operators of private pumping stations. Such disclosure provisions would require that operators of private pumping stations: 1) provide  the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) proof that the utility bills related to the pumping station have been paid; 2) provide relevant council members and community boards with information relating to who owns the station along with the contact information for such owners; 3) post signs indicating who is the owner and operator of the station with contact information and 4) certify to the Department of Environmental Protection. Local council member and community board that the pumping station is in good working order.

Name: Requiring DEP to post information online regarding scheduled and requested infrastructure services.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of environmental protection to post information online regarding scheduled and requested infrastructure services

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Environmental Protection to post information on its website regarding requests it receives and work it has scheduled, including catch basin maintenance, water quality testing, and sinkhole repairs.

Name: Requiring monthly reports on scheduled construction work on capital projects.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring monthly reports on scheduled construction work on capital projects

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance

Summary: This local law would require every City agency that manages capital projects to submit a monthly report to the Mayor, or an office or agency designated by the Mayor, which would detail all construction work scheduled in the ensuing three months and provide a status update on all construction work that had been scheduled during the prior six months. The Mayor, or office or agency designated by the Mayor, would be required to compile the reports of the managing agencies into a citywide which would be reviewed to promote coordination between managing agencies and to ensure that work on capital projects is being scheduled and conducted in an efficient and effective manner. The citywide report would be submitted to the Council, gas and electrical utility companies in the City, and the Empire City Subway Company, as well as be posted on the City’s website, in a machine-readable format.

Name: Permitting the appeal of decisions by the board of standards and appeals to the city council.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to permitting the appeal of decisions by the board of standards and appeals to the city council

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would require decisions of the Board of Standards and Appeals to approve a variance to be subject to review and action by the Council if the local community board or borough board recommends against approval of the variance and files a written objection. The Council would then be required to approve, modify, or disapprove the variance after a public hearing.

Name: Requiring an affirmative vote of at least two-thirds of all council members for the passage of any local law or resolution that raises taxes.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to requiring an affirmative vote of at least two-thirds of all council members for the passage of any local law or resolution that raises taxes

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would require a 2/3 vote, rather than a majority, by the Council for any local law that increases taxes, reduces or eliminates tax deductions, or increases fees.

Name: Increasing the minimum thresholds for eligibility for public funding for candidates for city council.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to increasing the minimum thresholds for eligibility for public funding for candidates for city council

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would increase the threshold required to obtain public funding for candidates for the Council to $10,000 in matchable contributions (up from $5,000), including at least 150 contributions from residents of the applicable district (up from 75).

Name: Decreasing the Campaign Finance Board’s public funding matching funds rate during times of fiscal emergency.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to decreasing the Campaign Finance Board’s public funding matching funds rate during times of fiscal emergency

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would reduce the public dollars provided to candidates participating in the City’s public matching funds program for elections in any year in which the Office of Management and Budget projects a budget gap of $2 billion or more.

Name: Procedures to be adopted by the 311 call center for responding to certain repeat anonymous complaints against the same property.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to procedures to be adopted by the 311 call center for responding to certain repeat anonymous complaints against the same property

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would require 311 to stop referring non-emergency, anonymous calls about harassed properties to agencies for follow-up. Harassed properties under this bill would be considered those that have had repeated anonymous complaints to 311 that cannot be substantiated or that are substantiated but are not illegal.

Name: Requiring defibrillators at softball fields where youth leagues play.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring defibrillators at softball fields where youth leagues play

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would require the City to provide automated external defibrillators (AEDs) to youth softball leagues playing on City-owned land at no cost. These leagues would be required to bring an AED to every game and practice, and to make efforts to ensure that a trained coach or umpire is present as well.

Name: Creation of a pilot program for the use of body-worn video cameras during certain sanitary inspections of food service establishments.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the creation of a pilot program for the use of body-worn video cameras during certain sanitary inspections of food service establishments

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health

Summary: This bill would create a one-year pilot program in which body-worn cameras would be worn by food sanitary inspectors in the course of performing sanitary inspections of food service establishments (FSE). The pilot program would require that cameras are worn in 10% of all inspections during the one year period of the program. The program would be limited to food service establishments subject to the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene’s (DOHMH) letter-grading program and exclude food vendors and other FSEs. The program would conclude after one year with the submission of a report by DOHMH to the Mayor and Council on statistics and recommendations relating to the program.

Name: Requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to make automated external defibrillators available to primary, intermediate and high schools.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of health and mental hygiene to make automated external defibrillators available to primary, intermediate and high schools that do not already receive such devices under any other provision of law

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health

Summary: This law would require the department of health and mental hygiene to make automatic external defibrillators available to primary, intermediate and high schools that do not already receive such devices. An automated external defibrillator is a device that can stop irregular heart rhythms or restart a heart after sudden cardiac arrest by conveying an electronic shock to the heart (through the chest).

Name: Certain fees for residential properties in the acquisition for redevelopment program.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to certain fees for residential properties in the acquisition for redevelopment program

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would permit the waiving of certain fees for residential properties in the acquisition for redevelopment program if certain design criteria are met.

Name: Creation of a remediation of unsafe flooded homes program.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the creation of a remediation of unsafe flooded homes program

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would create a Remediation of Unsafe Flooded Homes Program. Under this program, the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) would consult with the Department of Buildings (DOB) to identify and inspect 1-2 family homes that experienced flooding during Hurricane Sandy. Only homes that display (1) externally visible unsafe conditions, or (2) evidence that the home has been abandoned or vacant since Hurricane Sandy coupled with evidence that the home has been unremediated since the storm, would be inspected. The bill gives Council Members and Borough Presidents the authority to add homes to the program if they meet this criteria. HPD and DOB would order the correction of any violations and, if economically infeasible for an owner to correct them, may order a home be vacated, removed, demolished or may acquire the property using the power of eminent domain.

Name: Verification of asbestos abatement.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to verification of asbestos abatement

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require a Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) inspector to perform a site inspection and verify successful asbestos abatement before the Department of Buildings can issue any construction permits.

Name: Issuance of building permits for areas in which a certified rezoning application is pending.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the issuance of building permits for areas in which a certified rezoning application is pending

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require that the Department of Buildings not issue building construction permits for areas in which pending rezoning applications have been certified by the City Planning Commission unless the construction complies with the zoning provided for in the certified application.

Name: Dept of parks and recreation to post information online regarding a queue for street tree maintenance and sidewalk repairs and regarding street tree removals.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of parks and recreation to post information online regarding a queue for street tree maintenance and sidewalk repairs and regarding street tree removals

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation

Summary: This bill would expand on local law 65 of 2017 to require the Department of Parks and Recreation to post information online regarding street tree removals and the numbered position in a queue of upcoming street tree maintenance and related sidewalk repairs. Such information would facilitate public awareness of the removal of potentially hazardous trees and would allow individuals and public officials to track requested maintenance in their communities.

Name: Exempting certain cultural institutions located on property owned by the City from tree replacement requirements.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to exempting certain cultural institutions located on property owned by the City from tree replacement requirements

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation

Summary: This bill would exempt certain cultural institutions, such as botanical gardens, zoos and museums situated on City-owned property from tree replacement requirements pursuant to Local Law 3 of 2010.

Name: Exempting the Dept of Environmental Protection from tree replacement requirements when it performs construction work on Bluebelts.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to exempting the Department of Environmental Protection from tree replacement requirements when it performs construction work on Bluebelts

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation

Summary: This bill would exempt the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) from the requirements of Local Law 3 of 2010, that would otherwise require DEP to replace every tree it cuts down when creating or performing work on Bluebelts. The Bluebelt program is administered by DEP on Staten Island and is essentially a storm water management system that involves the protection of natural drainage corridors

Name: Undertaking of surveys before planting trees.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the undertaking of surveys before planting trees

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would require the department of parks and recreation to conduct a survey of the area within a 10 foot radius of a proposed tree planting site to confirm that planting a tree at such site will not interfere with usage of the street or sidewalk or interfere with water pipes, sewers, or other infrastructure near or underneath the tree.  The department of parks and recreation must make each completed tree-planting survey available online on its website.

Name: Delayed repairs to sidewalks damaged by city-owned trees.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to delayed repairs to sidewalks damaged by city-owned trees

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Parks and Recreation

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR) to provide notice to affected Council Members, Community Boards and Borough Presidents whenever work performed by or on behalf of DPR to repair a sidewalk damaged by a City tree is cancelled or delayed.

Name: Sale of aerosol spray paint cans and broad tipped indelible markers.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the sale of aerosol spray paint cans and broad tipped indelible markers

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This bill would require every dealer of graffiti instruments to request photo identification from the purchasers of aerosol spray paint cans or broad tipped indelible markers and conspicuously post a notice indicating the identification requirement.

Name: Prohibiting damage to houses of religious worship.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting damage to houses of religious worship

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This Local Law would amend administrative code section prohibiting damage to houses of worship to ensure language includes protection against damages to religious homes used primarily as residence for individuals devoted to religious life, such as convents and rectories.

Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to adjusting penalties for littering

Summary: This bill would raise the penalties for the second and third violation of public littering.

Name: Allowing the department of sanitation to purchase appropriate vehicles to utilize during a snowfall.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to allowing the department of sanitation to purchase appropriate vehicles to utilize during a snowfall
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This Local Law would allow the Department of Sanitation to purchase light- and medium-duty vehicles that can be used in response to a snowfall or other emergency that do not meet certain low-emission ratings.

Name: Allowing community service as a civil penalty for dumping.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to allowing community service as a civil penalty for dumping
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would allow for community service to be a civil penalty for dumping (transporting in a vehicle and illegally disposing of materials on public or private land) in lieu of a fine. Currently, fines, imprisonment, and vehicle impoundment are penalties for dumping.

Name: Pedestrian countdown signals.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to pedestrian countdown displays

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Transportation to install pedestrian countdown displays at any intersection where there is a photo-enforced traffic violation system.

Name: Requiring the department of transportation to post signs at intersections where speed cameras are located.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of transportation to post signs at intersections where speed cameras are located

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: The purpose of the proposed legislation would be to inform motorists that a speed camera system is operational in the area.

Name: Posting of a sign indicating that a traffic-control signal photo violation-monitoring system is in operation.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the posting of a sign indicating that a traffic-control signal photo violation-monitoring system is in operation

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: The purpose of the legislation would be to inform motorists that a photo violation-monitoring system is in operation in the area.

Name: Driving in bus lanes on snow days.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to driving in bus lanes on snow days.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: This bill would require that the City permit any person operating a vehicle when snowfall has caused the department of sanitation to suspend its street sweeping operations to be permitted to drive in bus lanes. This will enhance safety and provide clarity about the risk of receiving a violation or summons solely for driving in restricted lanes when road lines are difficult to see.

Name: Certain sidewalk repairs.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to certain sidewalk repairs

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would require that landowners be given at least 75 days, rather than 45 days, to make necessary repairs to the sidewalk adjacent to their property.

Name: Requiring the DOT to post information online regarding scheduled and requested street maintenance and traffic control changes.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of transportation to post information online regarding scheduled and requested street maintenance and traffic control changes

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Transportation to post information on its website regarding scheduled or requested street maintenance, such as resurfacing and pothole repairs, and requested traffic control changes, such as speed limit changes. It supplements the existing requirement that the Department post information on its website regarding a street’s last resurfacing and current condition rating.

Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to approval of cemetery uses on land acquired in Queens before 1973

This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use

Summary: This bill would allow a cemetery corporation that owns land in Queens to use up to two additional acres acquired before 1973 for cemetery uses, provided such land is across the street and such cemetery corporation first obtains approval for such use from the Council.

Name: Establishment of a retirement security review board.
Title: A Local Law in relation to the establishment of a retirement security review board
BodyName: Committee on Civil Service and Labor

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor

Summary: This local law would study the feasibility for a “pension for all” for private New York City employees.

Name: Establishing an anonymous wage theft hotline, a wage theft advocacy office and an annual wage theft hotline report.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to establishing an anonymous wage theft hotline, a wage theft advocacy office and an annual wage theft hotline report
BodyName: Committee on Consumer Affairs and Business Licensing

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs and Business Licensing

Summary: This bill would require the Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, or whomever the Mayor designates, to assist the Public Advocate in establishing an Office of Wage Theft Advocacy within the Office of the Public Advocate, to help workers file wage theft complaints with state authorities. This bill would also require the Commissioner or designee to establish a wage theft hotline to inform callers about the New York wage law and available resources for workers and, if the caller so requests, to send information about wage laws, including laws relating to wage theft, to businesses and employers. Finally, this bill would require the Commissioner or other designee to provide an annual report regarding the operation of the hotline and to make recommendations to the State Department of Labor regarding state labor law.

Name: Maximum fee allowed when transferring money to a city inmate.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the maximum fee allowed when transferring money to a city inmate

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice

Summary: This local law clarifies that an existing fee cap on transfers to inmate institutional accounts, established by state regulation (N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 7016.2(b)), also applies to wire-transfers. The law also caps the fee at no more than 1% of the deposit amount, not to exceed $5.

Name: Conducting audits of asbestos and lead inspections.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to conducting audits of asbestos and lead inspections

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection

Summary: This bill would require the Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) to audit no less than 40 percent of the asbestos inspection reports received by or filed with DEP. The bill would also require the Commissioner of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) to audit no less than 40 percent of the final lead inspection reports received by or filed with DOHMH pursuant to an order to abate issued by the DOHMH Commissioner.

Name: Creation of a comprehensive program to respond to air quality alert days.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the creation of a comprehensive program to respond to air quality alert days

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection

Summary:
This bill would established an air quality alert response program. The Council finds that air quality in New York City has been consistently in violation of the Clean Air Act criteria air pollutants standards since those standards were put into place. During the summer months ground level ozone and particulate matter (PM) concentrations routinely rise significantly above the national standards stated in the Clean Air Act of 0.075 parts per million (ppm) causing serious health risks, especially for the most vulnerable New York City residents. 

Therefore, the Council finds that it is in the best interests of the City to enact a more robust program for residents of the City, to be notified of, and protected on air quality alert days.

Name: Establishment of a preservation trust program with respect to certain tax liens.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the establishment of a preservation trust program with respect to certain tax liens

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance

Summary: This legislation would require the Department of Housing and Preservation and Development (“HPD”), in conjunction with the Department of Finance (“DOF”), to promulgate rules establishing a preservation trust program which would allow for the negotiated sale of tax liens on distressed properties to a trust created for the purpose of rehabilitating and preserving affordable housing. The legislation would also authorize DOF to sell such tax liens to a trust eligible under the preservation trust program and expand the definition of distressed property.

Name: Public notice prior to the permanent removal of any emergency medical service station.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York City charter, in relation to public notice prior to the permanent removal of any emergency medical service station.
BodyName: Committee on Fire and Emergency Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Fire and Emergency Management

Summary: This local law would require public notice prior to the permanent removal of any emergency medical service station. Such notice, delivered in writing at least forty-five days prior to permanent closing, must be provided to the council members, community boards and borough presidents whose districts are served by such facility or unit, and to the chairperson of the council's Fire and Criminal Justice Services Committee.

Name: Child care report and plan to address the need for expanded child care capacity.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to a child care report and plan to address the need for expanded child care capacity

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare

Summary: This bill would require the Administration for Children’s Services (ACS) to submit to the Mayor and Speaker of the Council and post on its website data related to child care enrollment and capacity, which would allow ACS to assess and track the service gaps that exist in different areas of the City. The bill would also require ACS to develop a plan to address the need for expanded child care capacity, including how to assist with the creation of additional subsidized child care slots, as well as overall child care slots, in the City. The plan must also address how to assist with the creation and maintenance of adequate subsidized and overall child care slots in areas that are experiencing significant economic transition and in higher-income areas where pockets of poverty exist. ACS would be required to submit to the Mayor and Speaker of the Council and post on its website an annual progress report, and to update the plan every four years.

Name: Requiring signage regarding application processing and fair hearings at job centers, SNAP centers, and Medicaid offices.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York in relation to requiring signage regarding application processing and fair hearings at job centers, SNAP centers, and Medicaid offices.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare

Summary: This bill would require require the City’s Human Resources Administration to post signs in every food stamp center,  job center, and Medicaid office that states the standard processing time for approval or denial of applications and information regarding an applicant's right to a fair hearing and how to request one as prescribed by the rules of the commissioner.

Name: Enforcement of the nuisance abatement law.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to enforcement of the nuisance abatement law

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would amend the Nuisance Abatement Law to add the Public Advocate to the group of officials who may request the Corporation Counsel to enforce certain nuisance related violations of the law.

Name: Promotion of health and safety at nail salons.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the promotion of health and safety at nail salons

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health

Summary: This bill would create a program recognizing nail salons that are healthier than otherwise required for employees and consumers. Nail salons would be permitted to apply for such recognition as a healthier nail salon by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, and in exchange would be required to abide by standards set by the Department for product safety, ventilation, and worker safety. Certified healthier nail salons would be eligible for reimbursement for part of the cost of a ventilation unit. The bill would also create a one-year, seven-member taskforce on health and safety in nail salons, with four members appointed by the Mayor, two by the Speaker of the Council, and one by the Public Advocate. It would be required to issue a report relating to a variety of nail salons health and safety issues, and recommendations for improving health and safety in nail salons.

Name: Information and city services to reduce college sexual assault.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to information and city services to reduce college sexual assault.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Higher Education

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) to provide every student at every college in the City with information about services regarding sexual assault.  It would require DOHMH to provide all students with an online tool with functionality for reporting sexual assaults and where they have occurred.  It would require the DOHMH to develop a sexual assault prevention and response curriculum that would include training in affirmative consent and on-campus adjudications for students, faculty, campus safety officers and college administrators.  Lastly, it would require DOHMH to establish a task force including representatives from certain City agencies to work with students and representatives of the faculty and administration from colleges and universities in the City to identify ways to improve City services and agency responses to college sexual assaults.

Name: Installation of protective devices for seniors and persons with a disability who reside in multiple dwellings, and the provision of a tax abatement for certain related installations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the installation of protective devices for seniors and persons with a disability who reside in multiple dwellings, and the provision of a tax abatement for certain related installations

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would require the installation in multiple dwellings of certain protective devices for seniors and persons with disabilities that enhance mobility, safety and the quality of life for such persons. These devices would be installed upon the request of a tenant and include such items as grabs bars in bathrooms and treads on the floors of tenants. There would be no cost to the tenant for the installation of the devices but eligible owners would be entitled to a tax abatement for certain related installations.

Name: Requiring the registration of owners of vacant property.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the registration of owners of vacant property

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would require owner of any real property in the city to register the property as vacant upon it being vacant one year.  Registrations would need to be renewed annually and failure to comply would result in a fine between $100 - $500 per week.

Name: Requiring the commissioner of HPD to report on the number of dwellings and dwelling units created or preserved through department programs.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the commissioner of housing preservation and development to report on the number of dwellings and dwelling units created or preserved through department programs

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) to report on the type and number of dwelling units created, sponsored, or preserved by HPD.

Name: Posting the number of workers present at a construction site.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city building code, in relation to posting the number of workers present at a construction site

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require construction sites to post the number of workers present at a jobsite.

Name: Maintenance of vacant buildings.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the maintenance of vacant buildings

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require the installation of internal metal security panels on buildings that have remained vacant and insufficiently secured for more than six months.

Name: Requiring the police dept to submit reports on enforcement of right of way violations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the police department to submit reports on enforcement of right of way violations

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This bill requires the NYPD to report on the number of violations issued for failure to yield to a pedestrian or bicyclist when pedestrians have the right of way, including the number of violations issued for simply failing to yield, the number of violations issued where the vehicle makes contact and injures the pedestrian, the direction of the automobile turn that caused the incident in question, the type of vehicle or vehicles involved in the incident, and the outcome of the adjudication of any such violations.

Name: Requiring the police department to report information gathered by ShotSpotter technology.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the police department to report information gathered by ShotSpotter technology

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This bill requires the NYPD to report on information detected by ShotSpotter technology.

Name: Requiring the NYPD to report on arrests of individuals under 18 years of age.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the New York City Police Department to report on arrests of individuals under eighteen years of age.

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This local law will require the Police Department to submit annual reports to City Council detailing the arresting charge, the age of the individual arrested; the race of the individual arrested; the precinct of the arrest; and whether or not the location of the arrest corresponds to the address of a school run by the Department of Education.

Name: Waste collection from nursing homes.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to waste collection from nursing homes
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Sanitation to collect solid waste from nursing homes at no cost to the nursing homes and regardless of whether the nursing home is a for-profit entity.

Name: Exempting or partially exempting seniors and certain persons with disabilities from penalties for failing to remove snow or ice from sidewalks, crosswalks, curbs and other locations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to exempting or partially exempting seniors and certain persons with disabilities from penalties for failing to remove snow or ice from sidewalks, crosswalks, curbs and other locations
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: The bill would require DSNY to establish a program to assist seniors and the disabled with snow removal from sidewalks abutting buildings such individuals own, lease or occupy and would reduce fines for failure to remove snow from these sidewalks by at least fifty percent.

Name: Requiring the registration and insurance of unmanned aerial vehicles
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the registration and insurance of unmanned aerial vehicles

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: This bill would require unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), including drones, to be registered with the New York City Department of Transportation (DOT) and to be covered by a liability insurance policy before they may be flown in City airspace. The bill would create exceptions from these requirements for toy aircraft (as defined in the bill), UAVs that are not flown in the City, and UAVs that are considered air carriers under federal law. The bill would also require each covered UAV to have a tag affixed to it with an identification number linking it to its owner. The bill would authorize DOT and other actors, including the Police Department, to enforce its provisions, and would allow authorized entities to temporarily seize a UAV that was in violation of the bill and allow DOT to impose penalties on the owner or operator after a hearing. Finally, the bill would allow the Commissioner of Transportation to promulgate rules and require him or her to report on the effectiveness of the registration and insurance requirements at protecting the public.

Name: Implementing a pilot project to reduce the number of crashes involving city owned motor vehicles.
Title: A Local Law in relation to implementing a pilot project to reduce the number of crashes involving city owned motor vehicles

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: The proposed local law would require the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) to conduct a year-long pilot program that would utilize collision avoidance technology on no less than 100 City fleet vehicles. The proposed legislation would also require DCAS to produce a report at the end of the pilot program discussing the impact of such technology on the incidence of vehicle accidents, the cost of such technology, and recommendations for expanding the use of such technology.

Name: A study on materials used to repair street defects.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to a study on materials used to repair street defects

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: The purpose of the legislation is for the Department of Transportation to study whether more environmentally sustainable materials may be used in repairing street defects.

Name: Establishment of a pilot program for the installation of dedicated left-turn arrow traffic signals at no fewer than 50 intersections in the city.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the establishment of a pilot program for the installation of dedicated left-turn arrow traffic signals at no fewer than 50 intersections in the city

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation

Summary: This bill would require the Commissioner of Transportation to establish a pilot program to install left-turn arrow traffic signals at 100 or more intersections in the City. The Commissioner would determine the particular intersections to be affected after considering relevant traffic guidelines and consulting with advocates and would be required to install the signals at a rate of 50 per year. The bill would also require the Commissioner to monitor the effects of the pilot program on the affected intersections and to post a report on the Department of Transportation’s website analyzing the status of the program.

Name: Requiring optional HIV/AIDS tests when anyone is released from a department of juvenile justice facility or a corrections facility.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring optional HIV/AIDS tests when anyone is released from a department of juvenile justice facility or a corrections facility

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Youth Services

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to offer juveniles released from a juvenile justice facility or a corrections facility, after serving more than six months, be given a free HIV/AIDS test.

Name: Creation of a division of LGBT youth services within the dept of health and mental hygiene.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the creation of a division of LGBT youth services within the department of health and mental hygiene

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Youth Services

Summary: This bill would establish of a division of LGBT youth services within the department of health and mental hygiene.

Name: Establishing a charter revision commission to draft a new or revised city charter.
Title: A Local Law in relation to establishing a charter revision commission to draft a new or revised city charter

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Mayor
This Introduction was Signed Into Law by Mayor
This Introduction was Recved from Mayor by Council

Summary: The bill would establish a charter revision commission to draft a new or revised City charter.

Name: Requiring the dept of education to report on funding for after school athletics.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of education to report on funding for after school athletics

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Education to provide a report on after school athletic funding to the Council and post the same report on their website. The report would include data with respect to funding for coaches, referees, athletic directors, equipment, uniforms, and transportation. The bill would also require reporting on student demographic information, athletic teams requests, and athletic facilities used for after school athletics.

Name: Signs near diaper changing tables.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to signs near diaper changing tables

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection

Summary: This bill would require that, where a building contains a restroom intended for public or common use, a building owner must post a sign in or near each restroom that contains a diaper changing table stating that baby wipes should not be flushed.

Name: Sale of nonwoven disposable products.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the sale of nonwoven disposable products

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would prohibit a retailer from selling a nonwoven disposable product unless it complies with testing standards established by the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection.

Name: Exemptions from the sale of tax liens.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to exemptions from the sale of tax liens

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Finance
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Amendment Proposed by Comm
This Introduction was Amended by Committee
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Committee approved by Roll Call.
A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
This Introduction was Sent to Mayor by Council
This Introduction was City Charter Rule Adopted
This Introduction was Returned Unsigned by Mayor

Summary: This bill would create a position of a not-for-profit ombudsperson within the Department of Finance (DOF). Moreover, this bill would exempt from the City’s lien sale any property owned by a not-for-profit organization that received a not-for-profit property tax exemption under in at least one of the prior two fiscal years, provided that: (1) such exemption was granted on or after the date on which such property was conveyed to a not-for-profit organization; (2) the property tax component of such lien arose on or after the date on which such real property was conveyed to such not-for-profit organization; and (3) such not-for-profit organization was organized or conducted for an eligible not-for-profit purpose. Additionally, the bill would provide an exemption for any property for which the owner has, in good faith, submitted a pending application for a not-for-profit property tax exemption pursuant to the above sections with DOF, as well as any property for which the owner is appealing the denial of such an exemption with the Tax Commission. Additionally, the bill would require notice to owners of Class 4 properties of the availability of exemptions and other actions to remove a property from the sale, as well as mandate certain other changes to the lien sale notice. Finally, the bill would require DOF to include information about how to remove a property from the lien sale when denying an application for certain exemptions.

Name: Requiring a monthly report to council members and community boards of certain permits issued by the department of buildings.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring a monthly report to council members and community boards of certain permits issued by the department of buildings

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill would require the New York City Department of Buildings to issue to each Council Member and community board, no later than the 10th day of each month, a report on New Building construction, Alteration Type-1, and full demolition permits issued during the prior calendar month for properties within the appropriate council district and community district, respectively. The report would include, for each permit: the name of the applicant; the location of the property; whether the property is vacant; and whether there are any open complaints for the property.

Name: Notification of intent to alter or demolish certain rent regulated housing accommodations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to notification of intent to alter or demolish certain rent regulated housing accommodations

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This bill changes the period in which inspection fees may be charged by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development under Local Law 65/2014.

Name: Requiring increased transparency regarding the sale of housing development fund company units.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring increased transparency regarding the sale of housing development fund company units

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings

Summary: This local law would require the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) to report to the Council on the average sale price of Housing Development Fund Company units sold within each Community Board District.

Name: Marketing of affordable housing units.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the marketing of affordable housing units

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would set requirements for the marketing of affordable housing which is funded in whole or in part by city financial assistance.

Name: Provision of community notification by the department of city planning upon receipt of a completed pre-application statement.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision of community notification by the department of city planning upon receipt of a completed pre-application statement

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use

Summary: A Pre-Application Statement (“PAS”) must be submitted to the Department of City Planning (“DCP”) prior to filing most land use and environmental applications, pursuant to 62 RCNY § 10-04. The PAS, which consists of a form and accompanying materials required by the form or by DCP, provides basic pertinent information about a site and proposed project. This bill would require DCP to forward copies of a completed PAS to each affected Borough President, Community Board and Council Member. DCP would also be required to post all completed PASs on its website.

Name: Fair Share - Improving community access to information about the siting of city facilities.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to improving community access to information about the siting of city facilities

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use

Summary: This bill would require the Mayor to include additional geographic detail about proposed new or altered city facilities in the annual Citywide Statement of Needs that is created as part of the City’s Fair Share facility siting process. In addition, the bill would require agencies to provide affected community boards and borough presidents with additional notice if a proposed city facility was not identified with sufficient detail in the Citywide Statement of Needs but the city proceeds with the siting.

Name: Tracking mitigation strategies in final environmental impact statements as part of the uniform land use review process.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to tracking mitigation strategies in final environmental impact statements as part of the uniform land use review process

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Subcommittee

Summary: This bill would require an agency of the Mayor’s choosing to include environmental mitigation strategies among the commitments tracked as part of the publically accessible online database tracking commitments made in relation to uniform land use review applications pursuant to section 206 of the Charter.

Name: Reducing civil penalties where food service establishments donate or recycle organic waste.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to reducing civil penalties where food service establishments donate or recycle organic waste

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Small Business

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Sanitation and the Department of Consumer Affairs to establish an organic waste donation and recycling program where food service establishments could have the civil penalties for eligible violations waived if they agree to donate or recycle their organic waste.

Name: Requiring the dept of sanitation to establish a plan for accepting commercial solid waste at city-owned marine transfer stations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of sanitation to establish a plan for accepting commercial solid waste at city-owned marine transfer stations
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This legislation, if enacted, would require the Commissioner of the Department of Sanitation to submit a report to the Mayor and the City Council by January 1, 2018 that would detail its plan to accept commercial putrescible and non-putrescible waste at the city’s four marine transfer stations.  The report would be required to include the date at which each marine transfer station would begin accepting such waste, the department’s efforts in attracting to each marine transfer station and whether the tipping fees associated with such waste would be subsidized in whole or in part by the City.   The legislation would also require that by March 1, 2020, and annually thereafter, DSNY submit a report on implementation of the plan, including the amount of commercial waste processed at each transfer station in the previous calendar year.

Name: Commercial waste collection zones.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to commercial waste collection zones
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would set benchmarks DSNY would be required to meet concerning the creation of a commercial waste collection zone system.

Name: Data Collection
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to data collection
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would require the Business Integrity Commission to collect an accurate customer register for each business that it licenses or registers, including the total volume or weight and type of designated recyclable materials collected and transported.

Name: Prohibiting commercial carters from hiring individuals as drivers in certain instances.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting commercial carters from hiring individuals as drivers in certain instances
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would require trade waste licensees and registrants to notify the Business Integrity Commission whenever they hire a driver who has a suspended driver’s license or who has been found guilty of reckless driving or driving under the influence of drugs or alcohol in the previous five years.  BIC would have the authority to revoke such licenses or registrations for trade waste companies that engage such individuals as employees or agents for purposes of driving vehicles for such companies.

Name: Signage in waste transfer stations.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to signage in waste transfer stations
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Sanitation to maintain a website regarding federal, state and local health and safety laws relevant to solid waste transfer station employees and for there to be signage in transfer stations informing employees of such website.

Name: Regulation of the heating oil supply industry by the business integrity commission.
Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter and the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to regulation of the heating oil supply industry by the business integrity commission
BodyName: Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management

Summary:
The bill would provide the Business Integrity Commission (BIC) with broad powers to comprehensively regulate the heating oil industry.   Among other things, BIC would be given authority to issue licenses and suspend and/or revoke licenses to and from heating oil industry participants, perform background investigations on license-applicants, and require fingerprinting of principals, employees and individuals employed by the applicants whom BIC believes may lack good character, honesty and integrity. 

In addition, the bill sets standards of conduct for licensees to protect against overcharging, shorting, and other forms of consumer fraud.  Requirements for licensees include registering all heating oil delivery vehicles with BIC; producing all heating oil delivery vehicles for inspection; maintaining records; billing consumers for heating oil in a form or manner prescribed by BIC; a prohibition against fraudulent schemes and business practices; and a prohibition against failing to cooperate with BIC investigations.  Violations would be punishable by both criminal and civil penalties, and by suspension or revocation of licenses.  In the case of unlicensed activity, BIC may impound vehicles.

Name: NYC agencies polices regarding work-related communications during non-work hours.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to New York City agencies policies regarding work-related communications during non-work hours
BodyName: Committee on Civil Service and Labor

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor

Summary: Employee use of work-related communications during non-work hours has become very common. This local law would require every City agency to generate a policy regarding the usage of City-owned mobile phones, City electronic mail and other forms of communication when employees are not at work. Such policies would then be submitted to the Mayor.

Name: Requiring the dept of correction to conduct a survey related to inmate quality of life.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of correction to conduct a survey related to inmate quality of life

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Criminal Justice
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee

Summary: This bill would require an annual survey of inmates in city jails regarding living conditions and treatment by correction officers.

Name: Requiring the DOE to provide school-level data regarding students receiving special education services.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of education to provide school-level data regarding students receiving special education services

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
This Introduction was Laid Over by Committee
This Introduction was Hearing Held by Committee
